thoughts.content: I’m investigating the horizontal scrollbar issue on the 404 page. I’ve got the 404.html, tuition-css, and a JS file. The problem might be caused by widths exceeding the viewport, fixed-width items, or certain CSS rules with global styles. I'll check the CSS for width problems, especially for elements like ".nf-wrap" and ".nf-card," and consider components that might still be active on the 404 page. I'll start analyzing the CSS for any overflow issues.

I suspect the .mobile-menu, which uses position: fixed and transform: translateX(100%) when closed, might be causing horizontal overflow. The transform moves it off-screen visually, but its bounding box could still be part of the layout. Even though the transform doesn’t always affect layout, it might influence the root viewport’s overflow, causing scrollbars.

I think when an element is transformed off-screen, its bounding box might still extend beyond the viewport, causing horizontal scrollbars—especially if the root's overflow is visible. Typical patterns use `overflow-x: hidden;` on the body to prevent this. However, using `right: 0` and `translateX(100%)` could also push the element’s right edge out of view and cause a scrollbar.

It’s common to set `overflow: hidden` on the body when the mobile menu is active. But when the menu is closed and off-screen, it could be causing horizontal overflow on the 404 page—especially with `transform: translateX(100%)` on a fixed-position `.mobile-menu`. Adding the `contain` property or adjusting the `inset` can help prevent scrollbars. However, setting the menu width to `80vw` and translating it by 100% might push its right edge beyond the viewport, causing horizontal overflow.

It seems the usage of `transform: translateX(100%)` on a fixed `.mobile-menu` can cause horizontal overflow if the body doesn't have `overflow-x: hidden`. The element’s bounding box extends beyond the viewport, triggering scrollbars. A typical solution is to add `overflow-x: hidden` to the body or HTML. However, other techniques include managing visibility or experimenting with different positioning methods for the mobile menu.

To fix mobile menu overflow, consider using `overflow-x: hidden` on the body or wrapping the menu with a fixed container that clips overflow. Additionally, setting `contain: paint` on the `.mobile-menu` can help reduce issues caused by transformed, off-screen elements. Further potential fixes may involve adjusting positioning or limiting the width of elements inside the menu.

The mobile menu’s off-canvas transform could be causing horizontal scrollbars. To fix, apply `translateX(100%)` to move it off-screen, and set `overflow-x: hidden` on the `html` and `body` for modern browsers. You might also want to use `contain: paint` to isolate overflow from the viewport. Checking for the scale behavior of other elements, like the WhatsApp button, could also help minimize overflow risk.

The overflow comes from the off-canvas mobile menu and possible WhatsApp button scaling. We can fix this with CSS by updating the mobile menu's transform and positioning, ensuring it's off-screen when inactive. Applying `overflow-x: hidden` to `html` and `body` should prevent any horizontal scrollbars without breaking other elements.

It looks like the off-canvas mobile menu's transform and width cause the issue. The mobile menu is pushed beyond the viewport (80vw), which contributes to horizontal overflow. A fix would be to adjust the `left`/`right` positioning when inactive, ensuring it doesn't push the page's width. Also, `html, body {overflow-x: hidden}` can help globally prevent this overflow.

The issue stems from the mobile menu's fixed width and transform properties, pushing it off-screen even when hidden — the browser includes this overflow in its scroll calculation. A solution would be either setting `overflow-x: hidden` globally or adjusting the off-canvas menu's position using `right: -100%`. You could also attempt `contain: paint` for the mobile menu or modify the CSS on the 404 page for a more isolated fix.

parts:
Short answer: the off-canvas mobile drawer is causing it.

# What’s overflowing (and why)
- Your 404 page renders the off-canvas drawer even when it’s closed:
  ```html
  <nav class="mobile-menu" id="mobile-menu" aria-label="Mobile navigation" aria-hidden="true"></nav>
  ```
  (present in the 404 markup). fileciteturn0file0

- In your shared CSS the drawer is `position: fixed; right: 0; width: 80vw; … transform: translateX(100%);`. That pushes the panel visually 80% of the viewport *past* the right edge. Most browsers include transformed fixed elements in the “scrollable overflow”, so the page becomes ~1.8× viewport wide → horizontal scrollbar. fileciteturn0file1

- You hide the mobile UI on desktop (`@media (min-width: 1200px) { .mobile-menu, .overlay { display:none !important; } }`), so the overflow tends to appear only on narrow viewports or when you resize the window below 1200px. fileciteturn0file1

Secondary contributors to keep in mind (not the root cause here, but worth hardening):
- If/when the floating WhatsApp FAB is present (`.whatsapp-button`), its hover scale (`transform: scale(1.1–1.15)`) can nudge a few pixels beyond the right edge on tight layouts unless you set a right-anchored transform origin. fileciteturn0file1
- Very narrow phones (<360px): you already add an override so the “Other” textbox can wrap and not force overflow; that’s good (keep it). fileciteturn0file1

The 404-specific “legacy suggestion” script and card don’t create fixed-width elements; they’re fine. fileciteturn0file2

# Fixes (pick one)
## A) Small, reliable patch (global safety net)
Add this once to your main CSS (or the 404 page’s `<style>` block if you want it 404-only):
```css
/* Prevent off-canvas/transformed UI from creating horizontal scrollbars */
html, body { max-width: 100%; overflow-x: clip; }  /* modern */
@supports not (overflow-x: clip) {
  html, body { overflow-x: hidden; }               /* fallback */
}
```
This is the least invasive and covers any future off-canvas elements too.

## B) Component-level fix (keep scrollbars normal elsewhere)
Constrain the drawer so its “closed” state can’t extend the layout:
```css
/* Drawer should not affect page width while closed */
.mobile-menu {
  /* unchanged: position: fixed; top:0; right:0; width:80vw; max-width:340px; height:100vh; */
  transform: translateX(100%);
  will-change: transform;
  contain: layout paint;        /* isolate its overflow from the page layout */
  pointer-events: none;         /* no stray hits while off-canvas */
}
.mobile-menu.active {
  transform: translateX(0);
  pointer-events: auto;
}
```
If you prefer not to rely on `contain`, pair this with the global `overflow-x` rule above.

## C) Nice-to-have hardening (optional)
```css
/* Keep FAB growth inside the viewport */
.whatsapp-button { transform-origin: bottom right; }
```
fileciteturn0file1

# Quick way to prove it (DevTools)
On the 404 page, open the console and run:
```js
document.scrollingElement.scrollWidth - document.documentElement.clientWidth
// then:
document.querySelector('.mobile-menu').getBoundingClientRect()
```
You’ll see a positive overflow value, and the drawer’s `left` ≈ viewport width with a `right` far past the edge—confirming it’s the culprit. fileciteturn0file0 fileciteturn0file1

---

If you want, I can give you a tiny diff that applies fix A to `tuition-css-1.0.1.css` so you don’t have to touch the HTML.

    About The Tutor

    Greetings! This is Dr Ng, a dedicated private tutor in Singapore, specializing in Mathematics for Junior College and Upper Secondary, as well as Mathematics and Statistics at the University level.

    I strive to create a learning environment that is both enjoyable and enriching, ensuring that every student has a fulfilling educational experience.

    More than 80 percent of my students have seen at least a two grade improvement after just a few months of tuition. Many have achieved distinctions in their final examinations.

    Academic Qualifications

    • Ph.D (Mathematics) from National University of Singapore
    • B.Sc. (Honours - First Class) from National University of Singapore

    Experience

    • Full time tutor since 2010
    • Both tuition centre and home-based
    • Well-versed with latest Ministry of Education (MOE) syllabus

    Various Levels Taught

    University Maths

    Mathematics at University and Polytechnic level is extremely broad in scope. I cover Probability & Statistics, Calculus of Several Variables, Linear Algebra, Analysis, Abstract Algebra, and Discrete Mathematics for Year 1 and 2.

    WhatsApp Me Now

    Junior College Maths

    Junior College (JC) Mathematics is where I have the most extensive experience. I provide focused tracks for H2/H1 Mathematics, H3 Mathematics, and H2 Further Mathematics -- all latest MOE syllabus.

    WhatsApp Me Now

    Secondary Level

    I tutor both Elementary Maths and Additional Maths for G3 and G2 students (latest MOE syllabus) and also provide coverage for Integrated Programme (IP).

metadata.reasoning_title: Extracting scripts from 404 page head

content.text:
<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8" />
  <title>Page Not Found - SG Maths Tuition</title>
  <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0" />

  <!-- Important: keep 404s out of the index -->
  <meta name="robots" content="noindex, nofollow, noarchive" />

  <!-- Early theme boot (mirrors index.html) to avoid FOUC -->
  <script>
    (function () {
      try {
        var saved = localStorage.getItem("theme"); // 'light' | 'dark' | null
        var prefersDark =
          window.matchMedia &&
          window.matchMedia("(prefers-color-scheme: dark)").matches;
        var theme = saved || (prefersDark ? "dark" : "light");
        if (theme === "dark")
          document.documentElement.setAttribute("data-theme", "dark");
        else document.documentElement.setAttribute("data-theme", "light");
      } catch (e) { }
    })();
  </script>

  <!-- Site CSS (inherits tokens + components for both light/dark) -->
  <link rel="stylesheet" href="/assets/css/tuition-css-1.0.1.

thoughts.content: I initially misread the `.mobile-menu { display:none !important; }` rule, thinking it was applied globally, but it’s actually part of `.no-js .mobile-menu`. This affects both index and 404, as they both have the `no-js` class on `<html>` until it's removed. I'll check if `tuition-js` handles this class, but I don’t have that file available to confirm.

I think both pages use `defer` to load the script removing the `no-js` class, which would display the mobile menu. But the overflow issue only appears on the 404 page. The mobile menu's width might be 80vw on the index, and I wonder if the `.overlay` interacts with it differently. Seems like the main difference is that the 404 may not have `overflow-x: hidden` set, allowing the horizontal scroll bar.

I thought `transform` wouldn't affect layout or cause overflow, and that seems true in most cases. Translating an element by `100%` of its width (like `80vw`) would push it too far right, beyond the viewport. But since `transform` doesn’t typically trigger scrollbars, that’s unexpected.

I’m wondering if the `transform` property can actually cause scrollable overflow. Usually, transforms don't affect layout geometry, so they shouldn't change the scroll width. But if `overflow: visible` is used and the element has `position: fixed`, that might be an exception which causes scrolling.

I need to evaluate whether the user's suggested change might be enough to fix their issue. The `overflow-x: hidden;` rule should block horizontal scrolling but may have side effects. I'll consider potential issues like fixed elements causing overscroll, interactions with `position: sticky`, and focus management concerns. Furthermore, possible alternatives like `overflow-x: clip` should be explored.

The user's suggestion to apply `overflow-x: hidden` on the body can indeed hide the horizontal scrollbar, but it won’t fully address the underlying width issue. Also, on mobile Safari, combining `transform` with `overflow-x: hidden` might cause rubber-banding. I should review the uploaded files to confirm the exact CSS details before providing a precise answer.

Adding `overflow-x: hidden` to the body usually helps prevent horizontal scrollbars by clipping overflow. However, some browsers treat the scroll container as the `html` element, not the `body`. To be thorough, it's typically better to apply this style to both `html` and `body`. Also, `overflow-x: clip` could be a better alternative.

Using `overflow-x: clip` is like `hidden`, but it completely prevents any scroll interactions. However, `clip` wasn't supported in Safari until version 16 (released in 2024). The user's suggestion of only using `overflow-x: hidden` is simpler, but it might interfere with `position: sticky` elements, especially on mobile Safari. For best results, a fallback to `hidden` is safer.

Many frameworks avoid applying `overflow-x: hidden` on the body to prevent conflicts with `position: sticky` on certain iOS versions. This setting prevents horizontal overscroll but usually doesn’t affect vertical `sticky`. However, toggling `overflow-x: hidden` alongside `overflow: hidden` might cause layout issues, especially with off-canvas menus. I should check for toggled styles in the CSS.

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en" data-theme="auto" class="no-js">

<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8" />
  <title>Singapore Maths Tuition - JC, University, Secondary</title>
  <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0" />
  <meta name="description"
    content="Ph.D. tutor in Singapore (15+ yrs). Individual & small group math/maths tuition: E Math, A Math; JC H1/H2/H3 Maths & H2 Further Mathematics; University mathematics." />

  <link rel="preconnect" href="https://www.googletagmanager.com" crossorigin />

  <script>
    (function () {
      try {
        var saved = localStorage.getItem("theme"); // 'light' | 'dark' | null
        var prefersDark =
          window.matchMedia &&
          window.matchMedia("(prefers-color-scheme: dark)").matches;
        var theme = saved || (prefersDark ? "dark" : "light");
        if (theme === "dark")
          document.documentElement.setAttribute("data-theme", "dark");
        else document.documentElement.setAttribute("data-theme", "light");
      } catch (e) { }
    })();
  </script>

  <link rel="preload" as="image" href="assets/media/hero-a-1536.jpg" media="(min-width: 1440px)" />
  <link rel="preload" as="image" hr

parts:
Short answer: yes, that single change will suppress the horizontal scrollbar—but make it a touch more robust.

# Recommendation
If you want a **one-liner** in your main CSS, prefer:
```css
html, body { overflow-x: hidden; }
```
Why: some engines treat the root scroller as `html`, others as `body`; setting both avoids edge cases where the bar could still appear.

If you’re okay with a slightly more “modern” version (still one rule):
```css
html, body { overflow-x: clip; }   /* cleaner than hidden; widely supported now */
```
(`clip` prevents horizontal scrolling without creating a scrollable overflow; if you need older-browser safety, stick to `hidden`.)

# Side-effects to be aware of
- This **masks the symptom** (off-canvas UI widening the page) rather than changing the drawer’s layout. That’s fine and common practice.
- Anything legitimately wider than the viewport (e.g., wide code blocks/tables) will be clipped instead of letting the user scroll horizontally. If you publish such content, add targeted allowances:
  ```css
  pre, code, table { overflow-x: auto; max-width: 100%; }
  ```
- Your mobile drawer is `position: fixed`, so it will still show correctly when opened; this rule only suppresses the off-screen closed state from creating page-level scrollbars.
- If any script temporarily does `body { overflow: hidden; }` to lock scrolling while the drawer is open, removing that inline style will restore your CSS rule—no conflict, just don’t re-enable with `overflow: auto !important;` (which would also reset the `x` clamp).

# Bottom line
Your proposed change works. Make it `html, body { overflow-x: hidden; }` (or `clip`) and you’re done.
